text: Docker tip: Use `restart: unless-stopped` on every service. Your homelab shouldn't need babysitting after a reboot. #selfhosted
Stop using `docker run` for everything. Docker Compose is free, readable, and version-controllable. Use it. #docker
Docker volumes > bind mounts for databases. Named volumes are managed by Docker, survive container recreation, and are easier to back up.
Use `docker system prune -a --volumes` to reclaim disk space. Old images add up fast when you're running 30+ services.
Set memory limits on your containers. One misbehaving service shouldn't take down your entire homelab. #homelab
Pin your Docker image tags. `latest` today might break your setup tomorrow. Use specific versions. #selfhosted
Docker networks: create custom bridge networks for each stack. Don't dump everything on the default bridge. #docker
`docker compose logs -f --tail=50` — your first debugging step for any container issue. Always. #selfhosted
Use `.env` files with Docker Compose. Hardcoded passwords in YAML files end up in git repos. Ask me how I know.
Docker healthchecks are underused. Add them to every service. Your monitoring stack will thank you. #docker
Caddy vs Nginx for self-hosting: Caddy auto-renews TLS certs with zero config. That alone makes it the default choice. #selfhosted
Traefik is powerful but over-engineered for most homelabs. Caddy does 90% of what you need in 10% of the config lines.
Self-hosting rule: never expose services without a reverse proxy. Caddy + wildcard DNS takes 10 minutes to set up.
Nginx Proxy Manager has a nice UI, but it adds a database dependency for something that should be a config file. Just learn Caddy.
Immich vs Google Photos: Immich handles facial recognition, ML-powered search, and mobile backup. 50MB RAM. Google wants your data + $30/year.
Immich is still pre-1.0 but already better than PhotoPrism for most use cases. ML features, mobile app, active development. #selfhosted
Running Immich? Enable GPU transcoding. Video processing drops from hours to minutes with even a basic iGPU. #homelab
PhotoPrism tip: Set PHOTOPRISM_WORKERS to match your CPU cores. Default of 0 auto-detects but sometimes underestimates.
Jellyfin vs Plex: Jellyfin is fully open-source, no account required, no phoning home. It just works. That's the whole argument.
Navidrome for music, Jellyfin for video. Don't make one app do both. Navidrome is lighter, faster, and has better Subsonic API support.
Jellyfin hardware transcoding on Intel N100: enable VA-API, pass through /dev/dri. 4K transcoding at 15W total system power.
Plex still requires an account and phones home. If that doesn't bother you, fine. But Jellyfin doesn't. #foss
Vaultwarden: 50MB RAM. Official Bitwarden: 2GB+ (MSSQL + .NET). For personal/family use, this isn't even close. #selfhosted
Running Vaultwarden? Enable WEBSOCKET_ENABLED=true and set up the /notifications/hub path in your reverse proxy. Real-time sync.
Self-hosting your password manager is the single highest-ROI self-hosting project. 10 minutes to deploy Vaultwarden. Years of value.
Home Assistant tip: run it on dedicated hardware, not in a Docker stack with 20 other things. Zigbee/Z-Wave timing matters.
Home Assistant is the one self-hosted app where 'just use the cloud version' is wrong. Your smart home shouldn't depend on someone else's servers.
HACS (Home Assistant Community Store) is essential. Official integrations are great, but HACS fills the gaps. #homeassistant
Syncthing vs Nextcloud for file sync: Syncthing is peer-to-peer, zero server maintenance. Nextcloud is a full platform. Pick what you actually need.
Nextcloud runs fine on modest hardware. 2 cores, 2GB RAM, PostgreSQL instead of MySQL. Don't let the 'requirements' scare you.
Syncthing conflict handling is elegant — it keeps both versions. No silent overwrites. No data loss. #selfhosted
WireGuard connects in under a second. OpenVPN takes 10-30 seconds. For mobile use, WireGuard isn't just faster — it's a different experience.
Tailscale is great but it's a company. Headscale gives you the same mesh VPN with zero external dependencies. Self-host your control plane.
WireGuard tip: use AllowedIPs = 0.0.0.0/0 for full tunnel, or specific subnets for split tunnel. Most people want split tunnel.
Every self-hoster needs a VPN solution. WireGuard for raw connections, Tailscale/Headscale for mesh. No excuses for exposing services raw.
Pi-hole vs AdGuard Home: AGH has a cleaner UI and built-in DoH/DoT. Pi-hole has a bigger community. Both work. I'd start with AGH today.
Run two DNS instances on separate hardware. When your single Pi-hole goes down for updates, your entire network shouldn't lose DNS.
AdGuard Home uses ~30MB RAM. Pi-hole uses ~80MB. Both are light enough to run on literally anything. #selfhosted
Uptime Kuma: simple, beautiful, and self-hosted monitoring. 5-minute setup. Notifications via Telegram, Discord, email. Zero config drama.
Uptime Kuma vs Grafana+Prometheus: UptimeKuma for 'is it up?' monitoring. Grafana stack for metrics and dashboards. Different tools, different jobs.
Monitoring tip: alert on symptoms, not causes. 'Homepage is slow' > 'CPU is at 80%'. You need to know what users experience.
Restic + S3-compatible storage (Backblaze B2) = encrypted, deduplicated backups for ~$5/TB/month. No excuses for not backing up.
The 3-2-1 backup rule applies to self-hosters too. 3 copies, 2 media types, 1 offsite. Docker volumes aren't a backup strategy.
BorgBackup tip: use `borg compact` after pruning. Freed space isn't reclaimed until you compact. #selfhosted
Kopia is the modern choice for backups. Compression, encryption, deduplication, GUI, and it supports every storage backend you can name.
Ollama + Open WebUI = self-hosted ChatGPT. Run Llama 3 locally with zero data leaving your network. 8GB VRAM minimum for usable speeds.
Self-hosting LLMs isn't just a privacy play — it's about control. No rate limits, no policy changes, no surprise billing. Your hardware, your rules.
Running Ollama on CPU? Set OLLAMA_NUM_PARALLEL=1 and use smaller quantized models (Q4_K_M). Surprisingly usable even without a GPU.
LocalAI is like having your own OpenAI API endpoint. Drop-in compatible. Point your existing tools at localhost instead of api.openai.com.
Intel N100 mini PCs: ~$150, 15W TDP, 4 cores, Quick Sync for transcoding. The best value home server hardware right now. Period. #homelab
Stop buying Raspberry Pis for server use. A used Dell Optiplex with an i5 outperforms a Pi 4 by 5x and costs the same or less.
Proxmox tip: enable PCIe passthrough for your GPU. One host, multiple VMs with hardware acceleration. #proxmox
Your home server doesn't need 64GB RAM on day one. Start with 16GB. Scale when you hit the ceiling, not when you imagine you might.
NAS vs mini PC for self-hosting: a mini PC with external drives gives you more compute per dollar than any pre-built NAS.
ECC RAM in a homelab is nice but not necessary. Your uptime requirements aren't the same as a bank's. Save the money for more storage.
CrowdSec is fail2ban on steroids. Shared threat intelligence + bouncer architecture. Free for self-hosters. #selfhosted #security
SSH hardening in 30 seconds: disable password auth, use key-only, change the port from 22. Three lines in sshd_config. Do it today.
Don't mount the Docker socket into containers unless absolutely necessary. It's root access to your host with extra steps.
Authelia or Authentik in front of every self-hosted service. SSO + 2FA. No exceptions. Your Jellyfin doesn't need to be password-only.
n8n is self-hosted Zapier with zero per-execution costs. 400+ integrations. I run 50+ workflows on a single $5/month VPS.
n8n vs Node-RED: n8n for business/API automation, Node-RED for IoT/hardware. Different strengths, different audiences. #selfhosted
Huginn: like IFTTT but you control everything. Monitor price drops, aggregate feeds, send alerts. Runs on 256MB RAM.
BookStack for team wikis, Obsidian for personal notes. Don't use a wiki for personal stuff or a notes app for documentation. #selfhosted
Joplin with WebDAV sync to your Nextcloud. End-to-end encrypted notes that sync everywhere. No Evernote account needed.
Gitea vs GitLab: Gitea runs on 256MB RAM. GitLab needs 4GB minimum. For personal/small team use, Gitea is the obvious choice.
Forgejo is the future of lightweight Git hosting. Community-governed fork of Gitea, same lightweight footprint. #foss #opensource
SearXNG: self-hosted metasearch engine. Aggregate results from Google, Bing, DuckDuckGo — without them tracking you. 128MB RAM.
MeiliSearch is the self-hosted Algolia killer. Typo-tolerant, fast, and the API is a joy to work with. #selfhosted
FreshRSS or Miniflux: replace your Google Reader nostalgia with a self-hosted RSS reader that you actually control. #selfhosted #rss
Miniflux vs FreshRSS: Miniflux is minimalist, Go-based, fast. FreshRSS has more features and extensions. Pick your style.
Monthly cloud costs I eliminated by self-hosting: Google One ($30) + 1Password ($36/yr) + Plex Pass ($120/yr) + VPN ($60/yr). Total: ~$55/month. Server cost: $15/month.
A $150 N100 mini PC replaces: Google Photos (free tier is gone), Dropbox ($12/mo), password manager ($3/mo), VPN ($5/mo). Pays for itself in 7 months.
Self-hosted email: $5/month VPS + $0 software. Gmail for business: $6/user/month. Family of 4 saves $19/month. #selfhosted
Myth: self-hosting is only for experts. Reality: Docker Compose reduced the barrier to 'copy this file, run docker compose up.' #selfhosted
Myth: self-hosting costs more than cloud. Reality: a $150 mini PC runs 30+ services. Try pricing that in cloud subscriptions.
Myth: self-hosted services are less reliable. Reality: my Uptime Kuma shows 99.98% uptime. Google had more outages than my homelab last year.
'But what about updates?' — Watchtower auto-updates your Docker containers. Set it and forget it. #selfhosted
What's the first service everyone should self-host? My answer: a password manager. Highest security impact, lowest maintenance.
Unpopular opinion: most people don't need Kubernetes for their homelab. Docker Compose handles 50+ services just fine. Save k8s for work.
Biggest self-hosting mistake I see: running everything on a single SD card. SSDs are $20. Your data is worth more than that.
The best homelab is the one that runs without you thinking about it. Automate updates, automate backups, automate monitoring. Then go touch grass.
What's your 'set it and forget it' self-hosted service? Mine: Pi-hole. Installed it 2 years ago, hasn't needed attention since.
Self-hosting your email is a rite of passage, not a recommendation. It works, but the maintenance overhead is real. Know what you're signing up for.
Hot take: the self-hosting community spends too much time on dashboards and not enough on backups. Your Homer page won't recover your data.
If your Docker Compose file is over 500 lines, split it into stacks. One network stack, one media stack, one productivity stack. Separation of concerns.
What service surprised you with how easy it was to self-host? For me: Vaultwarden. 3 lines of Docker Compose, done forever.
Cloud-hosted AI is training on your data. Self-hosted AI isn't. That's not paranoia — it's in the terms of service.
Use Dozzle for real-time Docker log viewing in your browser. Lightweight, read-only, and actually useful for debugging. #docker
Portainer is training wheels for Docker. Learn Docker Compose and you won't need a GUI to manage containers. #selfhosted
Cloudflare Tunnels: expose self-hosted services without opening ports. Free, encrypted, and no dynamic DNS headaches. #selfhosted
Always check your Docker Compose with `docker compose config` before deploying. Catches YAML errors before they become runtime errors.
Homepage or Homarr for your homelab dashboard. One config file, all your services in one place. Bookmarks are for browsers, not homelabs.
Label your Docker containers. `com.centurylinklabs.watchtower.enable=false` on databases you don't want auto-updated. #docker
Running Nextcloud in Docker? Use Redis for caching and set `memcache.locking` in config.php. Night and day difference in performance.
Proxmox vs bare-metal Docker: Proxmox if you want VMs + containers + proper isolation. Docker direct if you want simplicity. Both are valid.
Cron + `docker compose pull && docker compose up -d` is a perfectly valid update strategy. Not everything needs Watchtower.
Duplicati for GUI-based backups, Restic for CLI power users. Both support encryption and cloud storage. Just pick one and use it. #selfhosted
The hardest part of self-hosting isn't the technology. It's choosing which of the 50 alternatives to use for each service.
Use `docker stats` to see real-time resource usage per container. Your 'lightweight' service might be eating 2GB of RAM. #docker
Fail2ban on your reverse proxy, not individual services. One config protects everything behind it. #security #selfhosted
ZFS on your homelab storage is worth learning. Snapshots, checksums, compression — it's the filesystem that actually cares about your data.
Self-hosting DNS? Run it on a separate device from your main server. When the server goes down for maintenance, DNS stays up.

Docker Compose tip: always pin your image versions. Running `latest` means any `docker compose pull` could break your setup. Tag versions. Test updates. Sleep soundly.
PSA: `docker compose down` removes containers but keeps volumes. `docker compose down -v` removes EVERYTHING including your data. Know the difference before you learn it the hard way.

Docker networks are one of the most underappreciated features. Custom bridge networks give you: - DNS resolution by container name - Network isolation between stacks - No port conflicts Stop using the default bridge.
Memory limits in Docker Compose: ``` deploy: resources: limits: memory: 512M ``` One misbehaving container shouldn't take down your whole server.

Docker logging can eat your disk alive. Set global log limits in /etc/docker/daemon.json: ```json {"log-driver": "json-file", "log-opts": {"max-size": "10m", "max-file": "3"}} ``` Your future self will thank you.
Use `docker system prune -a --volumes` periodically to reclaim disk space from unused images, containers, and volumes. I freed up 30GB last time I ran this. Old images accumulate fast.

Docker health checks are criminally underused. Add them to every service: ```yaml healthcheck: test: curl -f http://localhost:8080 interval: 30s timeout: 10s retries: 3 ``` Your monitoring and orchestration tools depend on these.

Curious: what's the self-hosted app you've been running the longest without needing to touch it? Mine would be Pi-hole — set it up years ago, just works. Gravity updates itself, queries resolve, ads stay blocked.

Caddy vs Traefik for Docker reverse proxy: Caddy: simpler config, automatic HTTPS, works great for smaller stacks. Traefik: native Docker integration via labels, better for dynamic container discovery at scale. For most homelabs with <20 services, Caddy wins on simplicity.
If you run Pi-hole, pair it with Unbound as a recursive DNS resolver. Your DNS queries stop going to Google/Cloudflare entirely. Your server becomes the authoritative resolver.
Caddy is the most underrated reverse proxy in the self-hosting space. Automatic HTTPS, clean config syntax, and it just works. Traefik is powerful but the learning curve is steep for homelab use.
What's your go-to monitoring stack? I keep coming back to Uptime Kuma for simplicity, but Grafana + Prometheus is hard to beat for depth.
Healthchecks in Docker Compose catch silent failures before you notice. Add a curl or wget check to every service. Three lines of YAML that save you hours of debugging.
Unpopular opinion: you don't need Kubernetes for a home server. Docker Compose handles 50+ services on a single node just fine. K8s solves problems most homelabs don't have.
Restic snapshots are incremental and deduplicated. First backup: full copy. Every backup after: only changed blocks. A week of daily 200GB backups might use 210GB total storage.

PSA: Watchtower is deprecated. The containrrr/watchtower repo is archived. If you need container update notifications, check out What's Up Docker (WUCT) — it lets you review updates before applying them.

The N100 mini PC is probably the best value in home servers right now. 15W TDP, ~8W idle measured, quad-core, hardware transcoding for Jellyfin. Under $200. No reason to run a 200W tower for most self-hosting setups.

If you're self-hosting email (brave), use a smarthost relay like Amazon SES or Mailgun for outbound. Direct SMTP from residential IPs hits spam filters instantly. Your MTA handles composition, the relay handles deliverability.

The best self-hosted monitoring stack in 2026: Uptime Kuma for uptime checks (dead simple, 30MB RAM), Grafana + Prometheus for metrics dashboards, Loki for log aggregation. Skip Zabbix unless you're managing 50+ hosts.
If you're running Nginx Proxy Manager and want to switch to Caddy, the biggest win is automatic HTTPS. Caddy provisions and renews certs with zero config. No more expired SSL nightmares at 3 AM.
Unpopular take: Portainer is training wheels. Once you're comfortable with Docker Compose, a properly organized stack of YAML files + version control gives you reproducibility that no GUI can match.
Running Immich? Set UPLOAD_LOCATION to a separate disk from your database. Photo uploads are write-heavy and can starve your PostgreSQL instance if they share the same drive.

Authentik vs Authelia for SSO: Authentik has a slick UI and SCIM support. Authelia is lighter (~30MB RAM) and config-file driven. For a homelab with <10 services, Authelia. For anything bigger, Authentik.
Before you migrate to a new server, export a list of every running container and their compose files. `docker compose ls` shows all compose projects. Future you will thank present you.

WireGuard changed remote access forever. Under 100 lines of config, connects in under a second, runs on anything from a Raspberry Pi to a VPS. If you're still using OpenVPN for your homelab, it's time to switch.
Pi-hole tip: set your DHCP server to hand out the Pi-hole as the ONLY DNS server. If you list a fallback like 8.8.8.8, devices will bypass Pi-hole whenever it's slightly slower — and they will.

SQLite gets overlooked for self-hosted apps, but it's perfect for single-user services. Vaultwarden, Mealie, Linkding — they all default to SQLite and run great. No need to spin up PostgreSQL for everything.

Reverse proxy health checks: add a /health endpoint to your services and configure your proxy to check it. Traefik does this natively. With Caddy, use the health_uri directive. Catches downed services before your users do.

Self-hosting email is the final boss. You'll fight SPF, DKIM, DMARC, IP reputation, and blacklists. Mailu or Mailcow make it manageable, but if you just need transactional email, use a relay like Resend or Mailgun and save yourself the pain.

Docker network tip: create a shared proxy network for all services behind your reverse proxy. `docker network create proxy`. Add it to every compose file. Your proxy container connects to every service without exposing ports to the host.

Tailscale vs self-hosted WireGuard: Tailscale is easier (5-minute setup, NAT traversal built in). Self-hosted WireGuard means no third-party server in your path. For most homelabbers, Tailscale is the right answer. For the privacy-maximalists, roll your own.
Backing up Docker volumes: `docker run --rm -v myvolume:/data -v $(pwd):/backup alpine tar czf /backup/myvolume.tar.gz /data`. One-liner, no extra tools needed. Run it on a cron schedule.
Nextcloud tip: disable the apps you don't use. Every enabled app adds PHP overhead. A lean Nextcloud with just Files, Calendar, and Contacts is noticeably faster than one with 30 apps enabled.

Hot take: Jellyfin has caught up to Plex for most use cases. Hardware transcoding works, the mobile apps are decent, and there's no subscription or login requirement. Plex's advantage is now mainly its polished UI.

Want to test a self-hosted app without committing? Use a throwaway compose file in /tmp: mkdir /tmp/test-app && cd /tmp/test-app curl -O [compose-url] docker compose up -d Delete the whole directory when you're done evaluating.

The N100 is the best value CPU for home servers in 2026. 6W idle, 4 cores, hardware transcoding, under $150 for a complete mini PC. Anything more powerful is overkill unless you're running VMs or heavy ML workloads.

Healthchecks.io is great, but you can self-host it. Same codebase, same features, no external dependency. Monitors your cron jobs and scripts — alerts you when they DON'T run, not just when they fail.

Restic vs BorgBackup: Restic: simpler CLI, native cloud storage support (S3, B2), deduplication built in. Borg: faster for local/SFTP, better compression, more mature. Both are excellent. Pick Restic if you want cloud offsite, Borg if you're backing up locally.
Nginx Proxy Manager stores all its data in a SQLite database at /data/database.sqlite. Back this up. Losing it means reconfiguring every proxy host, SSL cert, and access list from scratch.

The biggest mistake new self-hosters make: running everything on one machine with no backups. Your hard drive WILL fail. Start with a simple rsync cron job to an external drive. You can get fancy with Restic later.

Traefik labels in Docker Compose are powerful but the docs are dense. Start with just three labels per service: - traefik.enable=true - traefik.http.routers.app.rule=Host(`app.example.com`) - traefik.http.services.app.loadbalancer.server.port=8080 That's a working reverse proxy config.
Uptime Kuma is the best monitoring tool for homelabs. Single binary, 30MB RAM, monitors HTTP/TCP/DNS/ping/Docker, notifications to everything. Install it first, before anything else.

Docker Compose restart policies: - no: never restart (for one-off tasks) - always: restart on crash AND on reboot - unless-stopped: restart unless you manually stopped it - on-failure: restart only on non-zero exit code For services, use unless-stopped. For cron-style jobs, use on-failure.

If you're choosing between Proxmox and bare-metal Docker: start with Docker. Proxmox adds a hypervisor layer that's powerful but complex. You can always migrate to Proxmox later, but Docker Compose gets you running services today.

Gotify is a self-hosted push notification server that's criminally underrated. 10MB RAM, simple REST API, Android app. Send alerts from any script with a single curl call. Perfect for cron job notifications.

Cloudflare Tunnels are the easiest way to expose self-hosted services without port forwarding. Zero config on your router, encrypted by default. The tradeoff: Cloudflare can see your traffic. If that matters to you, WireGuard + your own VPS is the alternative.
Vaultwarden uses about 50MB of RAM vs Bitwarden's 2GB+ (it's Rust vs .NET + MSSQL). For personal or small-team password management, there's no reason to run the official server.

Mealie is the most underrated self-hosted app. Recipe management with ingredient scaling, meal planning, shopping lists. Scrapes recipes from any URL. Runs on 60MB of RAM. If you cook at home, install Mealie.
Watchtower users: the original containrrr/watchtower repo is archived. The community fork What's Up Docker (WUD) is the active replacement. It adds a web UI and per-container update policies.

Obsidian is fantastic but it's not open source. If that matters to you, Logseq and SiYuan are the best FOSS alternatives. Logseq for outliner-style thinking, SiYuan for a block-based Notion replacement.

Docker logging can eat your disk. By default, containers log to JSON files with no size limit. Add this to your daemon.json: {"log-driver": "json-file", "log-opts": {"max-size": "10m", "max-file": "3"}} Caps each container at 30MB of logs.

The self-hosting community needs to talk more about disaster recovery. Running 30 services is great until your SSD dies. Test your backups. Actually restore from them. The backup you haven't tested is the backup that won't work.

Caddy as a file server — one command: caddy file-server --root /path/to/files --listen :8080 No config file needed. Built-in directory listing, markdown rendering, and HTTPS if you point a domain at it.

Navidrome is the best self-hosted music server for most people. 30MB RAM, Subsonic API compatibility (works with tons of mobile apps), web UI, no transcoding needed for modern formats. Plex and Jellyfin are overkill for just music.
docker compose down removes containers but keeps volumes. docker compose down -v removes volumes too. Know the difference before you wipe your database.

ntfy is push notifications done right. Self-hosted, HTTP-based, no app registration, no Firebase dependency. Send a notification from any script: curl -d "Backup complete" ntfy.example.com/alerts That's it. No SDK, no auth tokens, no nonsense.

Using Traefik? Enable the dashboard only on localhost: --api.dashboard=true --api.insecure=false Then access via SSH tunnel: ssh -L 8080:localhost:8080 server. Never expose the Traefik dashboard to the internet.

Stirling-PDF is the Swiss Army knife of self-hosted PDF tools. Merge, split, compress, OCR, convert to/from images, add passwords — all in a web UI that runs in Docker. No more uploading sensitive PDFs to random websites.

Firewall rule for Docker: Docker bypasses UFW by default because it modifies iptables directly. Fix it by adding DOCKER_OPTS="--iptables=false" to /etc/docker/daemon.json and managing port exposure through your compose files.
Gitea is what GitHub would be if it respected your resources. Full Git hosting with CI/CD, packages, and project boards in under 100MB of RAM. Perfect for private repos on your home server.

Crowdsec vs Fail2ban: Crowdsec shares threat intelligence across all installs — if an IP attacks someone else running Crowdsec, it gets blocked on your server too. Fail2ban only learns from your own logs. Crowdsec is the modern choice.

Best Docker image registries to learn from: - linuxserver.io — consistent, well-documented, s6 init - hotio — minimal, developer-focused - ghcr.io official images — upstream, latest features linuxserver images are the safest bet for homelabs.

Paperless-ngx tip: the consumption directory is a one-way inbox. Drop a PDF in, it gets OCR'd, tagged, and filed automatically. Point your scanner's output folder at it. Never manually organize a document again.

LXC containers are Docker for people who want real Linux instances. Full systemd, proper networking, real filesystem. Proxmox makes them easy. If you need to run something that doesn't containerize well in Docker, try LXC.

Self-hosting tip: keep a plain text file listing every service, its port, and its compose file location. When something breaks at midnight, you don't want to grep through 20 directories to find which service uses port 8443.

Homepage vs Homarr vs Dashy for dashboards: Homepage is the lightest (20MB, static config). Homarr has the best drag-and-drop editor. Dashy has the most widgets. For a clean, fast dashboard, Homepage wins.

Using environment variables in Docker Compose? Create a .env file in the same directory as your compose file. Docker Compose reads it automatically. No need for env_file: directives for simple key=value pairs.

The hardest part of self-hosting isn't setting things up. It's maintaining them. Updates, backups, monitoring, certificate renewals, disk space. The stack that requires the least maintenance is the one you'll actually keep running.

Forgejo just keeps getting better as a self-hosted Git forge. Lighter than Gitea, fully community-governed, and the migration path from Gitea is painless. If you're running Gitea and haven't looked at Forgejo lately, it's worth revisiting.

The single biggest quality-of-life improvement for any home server: automated backups with off-site copies. Restic + B2 costs pennies per month and means you can nuke your entire server without losing anything. Sleep better at night.

If your Docker containers keep running out of disk space, check `docker system df` first. You'd be surprised how much space unused images and build cache consume. `docker system prune -a` is the nuclear option. `docker image prune` is the surgical one.

Unpopular take: most people overthink their reverse proxy choice. Caddy with automatic HTTPS handles 90% of home server setups in under 10 lines of config. You don't need Traefik's complexity unless you're doing dynamic container discovery at scale.

VictoriaMetrics is worth knowing about if you're running Prometheus. Drop-in compatible, uses 7x less RAM, and handles long-term retention without the operational headache of Thanos or Cortex. Single binary. Works immediately.

The hardest part of self-hosting email isn't the setup — it's deliverability. You can get Docker Mailserver running in an hour. Getting Gmail to trust your mail takes weeks of warming up your IP, setting up DKIM/DMARC/SPF, and praying. Self-host everything except email. Seriously.

Quick healthcheck pattern for Docker Compose that actually works: healthcheck: test: curl -f http://localhost:8080/health || exit 1 interval: 30s timeout: 10s retries: 3 Pair it with `depends_on` conditions for proper startup ordering.

Anubis as a reverse proxy challenge for AI scrapers is clever engineering. Proof-of-work before serving content — bots pay in compute, humans barely notice. Won't stop determined scrapers, but raises the cost enough that most give up.

If you're running Immich, set up hardware transcoding early. Without it, video playback hammers your CPU. Intel Quick Sync on an N100 handles 4K transcoding at ~15W. Add `devices: [/dev/dri:/dev/dri]` to your compose file.

Watchtower (containrrr/watchtower) is now archived. If you're still running it, it works but won't get updates. DIUN is the recommended replacement — it notifies you about available updates without auto-pulling. You decide when to update, not a bot.

Tailscale vs Headscale: Tailscale is a polished product with great UX. Headscale is a self-hosted coordination server that speaks the same WireGuard protocol. If you want zero reliance on external infrastructure, Headscale + your own DERP relay is the way.

Running Docker on a Raspberry Pi? Pin your images to specific architectures. Pulling `postgres:latest` on arm64 works now, but some images still default to amd64 and you'll get exec format errors with no useful message.

Gotify vs ntfy: both push notifications to your phone. ntfy wins on features — UnifiedPush support, topic-based subscriptions, web UI. Gotify wins if you need a Go binary with zero external dependencies. For most people: ntfy.

People underestimate how much data Google collects from DNS alone. Every site you visit, every API your apps call, every ad domain your devices ping — all logged. Running your own recursive resolver with Unbound removes that entire surveillance vector.

Proxmox tip: don't allocate all your RAM to VMs at creation time. Linux VMs use balloon drivers by default — they'll request memory as needed. Over-provisioning slightly means your host has breathing room for ZFS ARC cache or container overhead.

Self-hosting your own Git forge? Forgejo is the community fork of Gitea after the governance dispute. It's lighter than GitLab (200MB vs 4GB RAM), has CI/CD (Actions), and the migration from Gitea is a drop-in database swap.

Monitoring stack recommendation: Uptime Kuma for simple up/down checks (beautiful UI, 5-minute setup). Graduate to Grafana + Prometheus when you need metrics history and dashboards. Don't start with the complex stack — you'll burn out before you learn it.

Uptime Kuma vs Healthchecks.io: Uptime Kuma: monitors your services from inside. Push/pull checks, status page, notifications. Healthchecks: monitors your cron jobs. Alerts you when a scheduled task doesn't check in. They solve different problems. Run both.

Unpopular opinion: Docker volumes are better than bind mounts for databases. Bind mounts let you browse files easily. But Docker volumes handle permissions correctly, perform better on macOS/Windows, and are the intended storage driver. For config files? Bind mount. For Postgres data? Volume.

If you self-host Nextcloud, do yourself a favor and add Redis for caching from day one. Without it, every page load hits the database. With it, session handling and file locking are dramatically faster. One extra container. Three lines of config. Night and day difference.

Watchtower (or its successors), healthchecks, log rotation — set these up on day one, not after your first outage.

Restic backup tip: use the --exclude-caches flag. It skips directories containing a CACHEDIR.TAG file (Docker build caches, node_modules, etc.) without you having to manually exclude each one. Smaller backups. Faster restores. Less wasted storage.

Authentik vs Authelia for SSO: Authentik: full identity provider, LDAP, SAML, OAuth2, admin UI. Heavier (~500MB RAM). Authelia: lightweight auth proxy, 2FA, ACLs. Much lighter (~30MB RAM). If you have <10 services: Authelia. If you need enterprise SSO features: Authentik.
